description: Represents the number one. It's a fundamental radical and component in many other kanji, used for counting, dates (like the first day), and indicating 'one of something'.
Represents the number two. Commonly used in counting, for the month of February (二月), and in various compound words.
Represents the number three. Used for counting, dates (the third day), the month of March (三月), and in words like 'triangle' (三角形).
kunyomi: み, み.つ, みっ.つ

description: Represents the number four. It has two common readings, 'yon' and 'shi'. The reading 'shi' is sometimes avoided as it has the same sound as the word for death (死).
kunyomi: よ, よ.つ, よっ.つ, よん

description: Represents the number five. Used in counting, time (five o'clock), the month of May (五月), and money.
Represents the number six. It's used in counting, for dates like the sixth day of the month (六日, muika), and for the month of June (六月).
kunyomi: む, む.つ, むっ.つ, むい

description: Represents the number seven. It has two common readings, 'nana' and 'shichi'. Used for the month of July (七月) and for the Tanabata festival (七夕).
kunyomi: なな, なな.つ, なの

description: Represents the number eight. Its shape is considered lucky because it widens at the bottom, suggesting growing prosperity. Used for the month of August (八月).
kunyomi: や, や.つ, やっ.つ, よう

description: Represents the number nine. The reading 'ku' is sometimes avoided as it sounds like the word for suffering (苦), so 'kyuu' is often used instead. Used for the month of September (九月).
Represents the number ten. This kanji is a fundamental building block for larger numbers, such as eleven (十一) and one hundred (百). Used for the month of October (十月).
Represents the number one hundred. The pronunciation can change depending on the number preceding it (e.g., 三百 is 'sanbyaku', 六百 is 'roppyaku').
Represents the number one thousand. Like 'hundred', its pronunciation can also change with certain numbers (e.g., 三千 is 'sanzen').
Represents ten thousand. This is a primary unit for counting large numbers in Japanese. For example, 100,000 is written as 十万 (ten ten-thousands).
This kanji means 'yen', the currency of Japan. It can also mean 'circle' or 'round', and is read as 'maru' in that context.
meaning_mm: ယန်း၊ စက်ဝိုင်း

description: A very common kanji for 'person'. The reading changes based on context: 'hito' when used alone, 'jin' for nationalities (e.g., 日本人 - nihonjin), and 'nin' for counting people (e.g., 三人 - sannin).
A core kanji meaning 'sun', 'day', or 'Japan'. It's used in days of the week (日曜日 - Sunday), dates (e.g., 26日 - 26th day), and in the name of Japan (日本 - Nihon).
meaning_mm: နေ့၊ နေ၊ ဂျပန်

description: This kanji means 'moon' or 'month'. It is used for Monday (月曜日 - getsuyoubi) and to count months (e.g., 九月 - kugatsu, September).
Represents 'fire'. It is the first kanji in the word for Tuesday (火曜日 - kayoubi).
Represents 'water'. It is used in the word for Wednesday (水曜日 - suiyoubi).
Represents 'tree' or 'wood'. It is used in the word for Thursday (木曜日 - mokuyoubi).
meaning_mm: သစ်ပင်၊ သစ်သား
